results.title: Tapdancin'
results.brief_description: Tap Dancin’ explores the survivors and revivers of the great days of tap dance through performance, interviews and vintage footage which includes the Hoofers, the Copasetics and Bill “Bojangles” Robinson.

results.title: Tango of our childhood
results.creator_credit: Albert Mkrtchyan and Armenfilm U S S R
results.brief_description:
This melancholic comedy is a story of post-war displacement and one man’s sense of conflicting loyalties. Ruben, an Armenian, returns to his family after the war, only to leave them to go live with a nurse who saved his life. His proud wife, struck by the insult, enlists the help of her children in order to entice her husband back to the family home. Lurching between the two homes leaves Ruben in a state of abject confusion about his familial duties and personal needs.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Mkrtchyan ; photography, Rudolf Vatinian ; music, T. Mansurian ; editing, S. Gabrielyan.
Cast: Galya Novents, Mger Mkrchian, Elina Agamyan, Narine Bagadasaryan, Samvel Sarkisyan, Azat Gasparyan.

results.title: Time to talk
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch Your Language”
Discusses the importance of the parents’ role in teaching their children to explore the world through talking, relating and feeling.

results.title: Talking shop: demands on language
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield, Australia. Dept. of Education and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch Your Language”.
A teenage boy and girl, when interviewed for vacation jobs in a store, reveal a limited capacity to express themselves. Describes their feelings about their jobs, their fellow workers and shows how they adapted to the situation. Useful for linguistics studies and career advisers. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels and tertiary teacher education.

results.title: Talespinners
results.brief_description: CHRISTOPHER changes his name (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir., animator, Cilia Sawadogo); A young boy decides to change his name many times but soon decides that his original name is just as good. Based on the book by Itah Sadu who also narrates the film. “Lights for Gita” (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir. Michel Vo ; animator, Gregory Houston); A young girl is excited about celebrating Divali, an old Indian festival that fills the dark with the light. Her excitement soon ends because of a storm. Based on the book by Rachna Gilmore. “The Magic of Anansi” (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir., animator, Jamie Mason ; animator, Luigi Allemano); Anansi a spider living in the jungle doesn’t think the other animals respected him so he sets out to gain the respect he deserves. Based on a West Indian tale and narrated by Winston Sutton. “From far away” (prod. Michael Fukushima ; dir., animators, Shira Avni, Serene El-Haj Daoud); A little girl tries to fit into a new school in a new country. Based on the book by Robert Munsch and Saoussan Askar. “CHRISTOPHER: please clean up your room!” (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir., animator, Vincent Gauthier ; animator, Jo Meuris); A young boy manages to scare his family and friends with his messy room. This soon changes thanks to a few friends. Based on the book by Itah Sadu who also narrates the film.

results.title: Reading for meaning: the Goodman Model
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch your language”
Understanding the reading process. Professors Ken and Yetta Goodman discuss the problems of the teaching of reading with a class of teachers in Australia. Docments some of their main propositions relating to language in use, miscue analysis and reading. Stresses the need to focus on the strengths of children and not simply the weaknesses.
Suitable for teacher level.
